Question_1.Context: Laser-induced graphene (LIG) is a form of graphene that is synthesized by irradiating a polyimide film with a CO2 laser in an atmospheric environment. This process results in a three-dimensional porous graphene structure.
Question_1.Question: What is the primary method used to synthesize Laser-induced graphene (LIG)?
Question_1.B: Irradiating a polyimide film with a CO2 laser
Question_1.Source: Laser-induced graphene (LIG) is a three-dimensional (3D) porous graphene material that is synthesized by irradiating a polyimide (PI) film with a CO2 laser in an atmospheric environment.

Question_2.Context: The mechanical properties of encapsulation materials, such as their Young's modulus, are important for the performance of physical sensors.
Question_2.Question: Which mechanical property of encapsulation materials significantly affects the performance of physical sensors?
Question_2.Source: Despite the importance of the mechanical properties of Si elastomers for the performance of physical sensors, few studies have been conducted on the characterization of pressure sensors based on the encapsulation layer.

Question_3.Context: In the context of LIG-based pressure sensors, the brittleness of the LIG material can lead to durability issues when exposed to external mechanical stimuli.
Question_3.Question: What is a critical challenge associated with the durability of LIG-based pressure sensors?
Question_3.C: Brittleness leading to exfoliation or fracture
Question_3.Source: The 3D porous structure of the brittle carbon nanomaterial that generates LIG can easily lead to the exfoliation, fracture, and plastic deformation of the LIG nanostructure when exposed to external mechanical stimuli.

Question_4.Context: Elastomeric encapsulation layers, such as those made from polydimethylsiloxane (PDMS), are used to enhance the durability of LIG-based pressure sensors by providing mechanical support against pressure.
Question_4.Question: What is the purpose of using elastomeric encapsulation layers in LIG-based pressure sensors?
Question_4.Source: By pouring a liquid elastomer onto the LIG and subsequently applying a curing process, the elastomer can create a uniform and compact coating on the LIG, similar to a composite structure. This coating significantly enhanced the durability of LIG against mechanical pressure because the elastomer supported the LIG against mechanical pressure.

Question_5.Context: The resistance of LIG-based pressure sensors changes when pressure is applied, which is attributed to the deformation of the 3D graphene structure.
Question_5.Question: What causes the change in electrical resistance of LIG-based pressure sensors when pressure is applied?
Question_5.Source: When pressure was applied, the thickness of the 3D LIG decreased owing to structural compression, hindering electrons from traveling through the conductive area.

Question_6.Context: The response time of a pressure sensor is defined as the duration required for the resistance change to reach a certain percentage of the total resistance change when pressure is applied.
Question_6.Question: How is the response time of a pressure sensor defined?
Question_6.A: Time taken to return to initial resistance after pressure is removed
Question_6.B: Time taken to reach maximum resistance after pressure is applied
Question_6.C: Duration required for the resistance change to reach 10-90% of the total resistance change
Question_6.D: Duration required for the sensor to stabilize after multiple pressure cycles
Question_6.Source: To measure this, we subjected all the fabricated sensors to pressures ranging from 100 to 400 kPa. For the evaluation, the response time was defined as the duration required for the resistance change to reach 10–90% of the total resistance change.

Question_7.Context: The Young's modulus of an encapsulation material influences the resistance change and response time of LIG-based pressure sensors.
Question_7.Question: How does the Young's modulus of an encapsulation material affect LIG-based pressure sensors?
Question_7.A: A higher Young's modulus leads to increased resistance change and decreased response time
Question_7.B: A lower Young's modulus leads to increased resistance change and increased response time
Question_7.C: A higher Young's modulus leads to decreased resistance change and increased response time
Question_7.D: A lower Young's modulus has no effect on resistance change or response time
Question_7.Source: We confirmed that as the Young’s moduli of the encapsulation materials decreased, the resistance change increased, and the response time increased.

Question_8.Context: The environmental stability of LIG-based pressure sensors can be assessed by conducting accelerated-degradation tests, such as continuous exposure to high temperatures.
Question_8.Question: How can the environmental stability of LIG-based pressure sensors be assessed?
Question_8.A: By measuring the change in weight over time
Question_8.B: By continuously measuring base resistance changes at high temperatures
Question_8.C: By testing the sensor's response to varying humidity levels
Question_8.D: By observing color changes in the sensor material
Question_8.Source: Accelerated-degradation tests were conducted by continuously measuring base resistance changes of the fabricated pressure sensors with different elastomer-based encapsulation layers in an 85 ℃ oven.

Question_9.Context: The mechanical stability of LIG-based pressure sensors can be evaluated by subjecting them to repeated cycles of mechanical pressure and measuring the resistance change.
Question_9.Question: How is the mechanical stability of LIG-based pressure sensors evaluated?
Question_9.A: By measuring the change in resistance after a single application of pressure
Question_9.B: By observing the sensor's physical appearance after pressure is applied
Question_9.C: By conducting a tensile test on the sensor material
Question_9.D: By repeatedly applying pressure and measuring resistance change
Question_9.Source: The mechanical stabilities of various encapsulation layers were evaluated through cyclic operations. Pressure sensors with different encapsulation layers were tested by repeatedly applying a pressure of 400 kPa, which resulted in a resistance-change measurement during cycling.

Question_10.Context: The encapsulation layer of LIG-based pressure sensors can be made from various elastomers, such as PDMS and Ecoflex, which have different ratios of base to curing agent to control their mechanical properties.
Question_10.Question: What is the purpose of varying the ratio of base to curing agent in elastomers used for encapsulation layers of LIG-based pressure sensors?
Question_10.A: To control the color of the encapsulation layer
Question_10.B: To adjust the electrical conductivity of the encapsulation layer
Question_10.C: To control the mechanical properties of the encapsulation layer
Question_10.D: To change the thermal expansion coefficient of the encapsulation layer
Question_10.Source: In this step, we utilized various elastomer layers, such as PDMS 5:1, PDMS 10:1, PDMS 20:1, and Ecoflex 1:1, by varying the ratio of the base to the curing agent to control the mechanical properties of the encapsulation layer after curing.
